US MARKET WRAP - 14 JUNE 2019: Upbeat data lifts hopes on US economy
content:
• * SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries flat, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • * REAR VIEW: Retail Sales/Industrial Production strong; Fed June rate cut pricing eases; Trump says attacks have Iran “written all over it”, reiterates Fed criticisms; US & China agree to suspend WTO IP dispute.
  • * NEXT WEEK: Mon; US hearing on further China tariffs, Tues; RBA Minutes, German ZEW Sentiment, EZ CPI (Final), US Housing Starts, Wed; FOMC Monetary Policy meeting, CBRT Summary of the MPC meeting, BCB Monetary Policy meeting, Japan Trade Balance, UK & Canada CPI, Thurs; Bank of England Monetary Policy meeting, BoJ Monetary Policy meeting, Norges Bank Monetary Policy meeting, Bank of Indonesia Monetary Policy meeting, UK Retail Sales, US Philly Fed, Friday; EU Summit (EU top jobs decision to be made), Quadruple Witching, Japanese CPI, EZ and US Markit Services, Manufacturing & Composite PMIs (Flash), Canada Retail Sales, US Existing Home Sales.
  • * RANsquawk Week in Focus - Week Commencing 17th June 2019: To download the report, please click here.

* US RETAIL SALES: US Retail Sales M/M +0.5% in May, short of the 0.6% expected; the other measures surprised to the upside, however, painting a solid picture of consumer health. "Big upward revisions to prior data make this a very solid report," Pantheon Macroeconomics said. "We have been expecting upward revisions; the initial prints in March and April were hard to square with survey evidence, and history shows that the official data are much more likely to be revised up than down." As a result of the revisions, Q2 control sales will likely print +6.0% annualised increase, which would be the strongest since Q4 2017. "In short, the consumer is back after the weakness in the winter, when the boost from the tax cuts faded," Pantheon says, "overall, the data suggest that total real consumers' spending rose by about 0.5% month-to-month, keeping it on course to rise by 3.2-to-3.5% in the second quarter," adding that "the modest 1.3% Q1 increase was not an indication of a rolling over in the trend." Pantheon argues that real after-tax income growth is quite strong, and confidence is very high, so it expects H2 spending growth to average about 2-2.5%.

* US UNI OF MICH: Headline sentiment fell to 97.9 from 100.0, a slight miss of the 98.0 consensus. The data was more benign than implied by the TIPP Online data. However, expectations did fall by more than expected, while conditions rose unexpectedly. The key stands out were the inflation expectations gauges, which both fell; the one-year outlook slipped to 2.6% from 2.9%, and the 5-10 year gauge fell to a record low 2.2% from 2.6% -- challenging the notion that inflation weakness is 'transitory'. "We’re guessing that responses to consumer surveys in recent weeks have been heavily dependent on timing, given the chaotic announcement and then abandonment of tariffs on Mexican imports," Pantheon Macroeconomics said. "Some 40% of respondents to the Michigan survey mentioned tariffs, unprompted." The consultancy notes that, short-term noise aside, consumer confidence remains very elevated, and consistent with rapid growth in spending. "The constraint on spending growth is the rate of increase of real after-tax incomes - solid but not spectacular - rather than confidence," it says, "that suggests a trend of about 2.5%."

* US BUSINESS INVENTORIES: Rose 0.5% in April, with analysts attributing the rise to stock builders by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers. The inventory to sales ratio rose to 1.39 months from 1.38. "While inventories are poised to be a sizable drag, we now see upside risk to our Q2 real GDP growth forecast of 1.3% after this morning’s solid retail sales and inventories data," Oxford Economics said, "we expect businesses to manage with relatively leaner inventory levels in the coming months, following the largely involuntary inventory build early in 2019."

* US INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION: Rose +0.4% M/M in May, eating the consensus +0.2%. Manufacturing production rose 0.2% in line with the consensus, while capacity utilisation rose more thna expected to 78.1%. "The capex-sensitive business equipment category rose by 0.2% following last month’s decline," Goldman Sachs notes, and "the utilities component, an input into consumption in the GDP accounts, rebounded sharply (+2.1)." After the data, Goldman boosted its Q2 GDP tracking estimate by four tenths to +1.6% (qoq ar).

* IRAN: US President Trump echoed Secretary of State Pompeo's Thursday comments, saying that the tanker attacks in the Gulf of Oman have Iran “written all over it”, adding that he would not let them shut the Strait of Hormuz. As the US stance shifts more hawkish over Iran, the OPEC member’s President Rouhani said that Iran should strengthen its ties with Russia, who too are headway against the US. Trump did reiterate his previous stance that he is not looking “to hurt” Iran but caveated it by saying they could not be allowed to have nuclear weapons.

* TRUMP INTERVIEW(S): US President Trump gave another wide-ranging interview on Fox News. On Iran, he said the Gulf of Oman tanker attacks have Iran "written all over it", and intimated that there'd be repercussions if the nation closed the Straits of Hormuz, saying if that happened, it would be "short-lived."; he later added that he was not looking to hurt Iran, but it cannot have nuclear weapons. Trump also gave an exclusive interview to ABC, where he renewed criticism of the Fed, saying that the Fed Chair was his pick, but he "disagrees with him entirely". He said that the market would be stronger "if we had a different person in the Federal Reserve who wouldn’t have raised interest rates so much”, and when he was asked whether he has concerns that his repeated criticism of Fed puts Powell "in a box", he replied that he dues, "but I'm gonna do it anyway because I've waited long enough.” Trump repeated his view that he thinks the market [assume Dow] could be 10,000 points higher if the Federal Reserve hadn’t hiked rates last year, while also repeating that there's no inflation in the US. On China, Trump repeated his accusation that it manipulates its currency, and said it does not matter if China President Xi did not attend the G20 (he has previously threatened to apply tariffs on the remaining portion of Chinese imports if Xi did not meet with him at the G20.

* CHINA/TRADE: A WTO dispute panel on Friday said the US and China have agreed a suspension of legal proceedings in the intellectual property dispute until December 31st. Elsewhere, China's Foreign Ministry said it had lodged stern representations to the US regarding Hong Kong, and summoned senior US embassy official and demanding the US to stop interfering in its affairs immediately. Later, an SCMP article claimed China and Russia could be about to upgrade their relationship to something close to an alliance, as both try to fend off pressure from the West.

* INDIA: India is reportedly preparing to impose higher tariffs on over 20 US goods next week, including almonds, walnuts and apples. This follows the Trump administration recently scrapping trade privileges for India under the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP).

* TURKEY: On Friday, Turkey’s Foreign Minister stated that it will retaliate in the event that the US imposes sanctions due to the S-400 missile system; on Thursday, Turkey said that they will not back down from the S-400 deal with Russia and adding, in what was seemingly an explicit message to the US, that no country had the right to give Turkey an ultimatum. The US has recently been upping the pressure on Turkey to drop the Russian-made missile system; on Thursday, a letter sent by the US warned “there is strong bipartisan US Congressional determination to see CAATSA sanctions imposed on Turkey if Turkey acquires the S-400” and US Acting Defence Secretary Shanahan, who gave the country until 31 July to drop the deal with Russia.

* BREXIT: After leading the First Ballot by a greater margin than was expected, some Tory leaders are mulling joining forces in an effort to thwart the leadership bid of Brexiteer Boris Johnson. Matt Hancock pulled out of the race, with analysts suggesting it was a move designed to undilute the candidate choices, to try and rally support around pro-EU candidates that can challenge Johnson. Johnson later commented that he isn’t aiming for a no-deal and he doesn’t want no-deal as an outcome, although he refrained from taking the possibility of the outcome off of the table as expected. He also stated that he is happy to partake in the BBC TV debate on Tuesday, after prior speculation that he would skip the event. Note: Channel 4 hosts its debate on Sunday, which Johnson is currently not due to partake in, with the BBC TV debate to occur on Tuesday.

* WTI FUTURES (N9) SETTLE USD 0.23 HIGHER AT USD 52.51/BBL; BRENT (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.70 HIGHER AT USD 62.01: Crude traded choppy on Friday, with benchmarks trading range-bound/lower in most of the session, before heading higher into the close, but remaining beneath Thursday’s geopolitically-induced highs. The market seemingly returned to its demand focused downward path early in the session; PVM analysts described Thursday as having “all the hallmarks of an algo-triggered kneejerk reaction.” It is too early to determine whether the bounce on Thursday was a temporary “hiccup”, given the increased acknowledgement among US officials that Iran was behind the tanker attacks, with potential for further escalation in the oil rich region. Analysts at Citi said that “the market price action implies a low probability that the conflict would spiral out of control in that way.” The market is likely to be looking for further confirmation of a shift in tensions for it to rally in the face of faltering global demand.

* IEA MONTHLY REPORT: In fitting with both the EIA and OPEC, the IEA cut its 2019 global oil demand growth forecast by 100K BPD to 1.2mln BPD. Like OPEC, the IEA acknowledged a slowdown in oil demand growth in H1 but expects a pickup to 1.6mln BPD in H2. The report acknowledged the drop in OPEC supply, and expects Non-OPEC supply growth to accelerate from 1.9mln BPD in 2019 to 2.3mln BPD in 2020.

* US T-Note futures (M9) 2 ticks lower at 126-30: A solid batch of data out of the US saw the curve bear-flatten, with shorter-dated yields rising about 2bps (at settle) vs yields on 30s declining by around 1bps. Early trade was defined by risk-off type flows, which led to some concerns that the 10-year yield could breach the 2.00% mark. However, haven trade was usurped by decent fundamentals, with traders reducing bets that the Fed could cut rates next week in wake of the upbeat data. The implied probability of a June rate cut has fallen to around 25% from around 33% on Thursday, while July pricing eased slightly too. However, the TPLEX found buyers after the inflation gauges in the Michigan Sentiment data declined sharply, challenging Fed Chair Powell's view that inflation weakness was transitory, and perhaps giving further credence to the notion that the Fed has grounds to cut based on inflation alone, let alone for "insurance" reasons to guard against the fall-out from global trade tensions. At settlement, major curve spreads were narrower to the tune of 2bps.

* S&P 500 -0.2% at 2887, NASDAQ-100 -0.4% at 7479, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26090, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, Consumer Staples 0%, Energy -0.7%, Financials 0.3%, Health Care -0.3%, Industrials -0.4%, Information Technology -0.8%, Materials -0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities 1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Broadcom (AVGO) sunk after market on Thursday, after cutting its FY19 revenue view, and warned it sees “a broad-based slowdown in the demand environment,” comments which dragged the broader semiconductor sector lower, including heavyweights Intel (INTC), Nvidia (NVDA) and Qualcomm (QCOM) who finished in the red. Facebook (FB) moved higher on the news that over a dozen companies, including Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), PayPal (PYPL) and Uber (UBER) have signed up to back Facebook’s soon to be released cryptocurrency. Tesla (TSLA) moved lower after the electric automaker had an additional request for tariff exemptions rejected by the US government, but went flat on a report from Elektrek suggesting the automaker is on track for a record quarter. Shares of Sony’s ADR (SNE) moved higher after it received a USD 1.5bln investment from hedge fund Third Point, which called on it to spin-off its image sensor arm. Twitter (TWTR) edged higher as the tech sector fell, after the co deleted thousands of accounts tied to Iran and upped its efforts to end false information campaigns. FedEx (FDX) fell after China launched an enquiry into its recent Huawei delivery mistakes. Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) spiked higher on the news the DoJ were nearing approval for the merger, although the DoJ are said to be maintaining there demands for the two to divest assets for the merger to be approved. Verizon (VZ) also spiked higher, on news the telecoms co. is to build a fiber-based distribution network connecting the NBA's 29 arenas.

* FX WRAP: USD was supported by haven demand in early trade, finding a further boost from solid data which weighed on Fed rate cut pricing. EUR and GBP both eased as the buck picked up, with the former sliding beneath 1.13 towards 1.12, while the latter continues to feel the impact of Brexiteer Boris Johnson leading the race to become PM; GBP took out last week’s low and trades sub 1.26. JPY continues to be uneventful and sticks within the 108.00-108.50 range, although XAU backed-off highs, as solid data somewhat reduces the chances of immediate Fed rate cuts, while Michigan Consumer sentiment data saw inflation gauges fall sharply. CAD took its cue more from the stronger dollar, as opposed to oil prices, and USDCAD topping 1.34 level. AUD sunk back towards its May lows, trades sub-0.69 heading into the weekend, ahead of next week’s RBA minutes; more banks have joined the chorus calling for further rate cuts after this week’s disappointing jobs data. NZD fell after disappointing survey data. EMFX was mixed; BRL sunk on reports that lawmakers had given into the public servant’s lobby, who had been working to halt pension reform. RUB was a little firmer, largely unaffected as the Russian Central Bank opted to cut rates (as expected) and Governor Nabiullina delivering dovish remarks. TRY was under pressure after the Turkish government threatened to retaliate to any US sanctions relating to the Russian S-400 missile system.

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: firm Friday data dampens Fed rate cut furore
content:
DXY

The broad Dollar and index accordingly are ending the week on the up as US retail sales came in above expectations and were embellished by significant back month upgrades (to positive from negative and +0.4% from flat for the key control group) before ip beat consensus to provide a bit more positivity. The DXY has extended recovery gains to 97.413 and through pre-NFP highs (97.370) vs 96.578 lows posted after benign PPI and CPI reports boosted Fed easing probabilities to 30%+ for next week’s FOMC and over 90% for the July policy meeting. However, at least one insurance cut is still widely anticipated so the index may fade ahead of 97.500 and the next upside chart target at 97.546 (late May pull-back low and only a day after hitting the current 98.371 ytd best), especially with inflation expectations via the University of Michigan falling markedly. On the flip-side, the Greenback has benefited from its safe-haven status amidst heightened global trade and geopolitical strains with only the Yen, Gold and a select few other rival currencies outperforming or strong on specific impulses.

JPY 

As noted above, Usd/Jpy and Jpy crosses have been trending lower on mainly risk-off grounds as relations between the US and China/Iran/Turkey/India/Russia and the EU etc deteriorated on tariff and/or diplomatic issues and another oil tanker attack soured sentiment on supply concerns. The headline pair has been largely below 108.50 within a 108.79-14 range and also capped by dovish BoJ vibes ahead of next Friday’s policy convene plus pledges of fiscal stimulus from Japan’s Government.

AUD/NZD/CAD

The non-US Dollars are all heading for net and hefty losses vs the Greenback with the Aussie slipping further below 0.6900 in wake of mixed to weak jobs data that underpinned forecasts for further RBA easing, and even prompted some to target a lower OCR than previously anticipated. Similarly, the Kiwi is now hovering precariously above 0.6500, partly in sympathy with its Antipodean counterpart, but also as NZ manufacturing PMI only just avoided contraction to raise question marks over recent RBNZ guidance for steady policy for the foreseeable future per Assistant Governor Hawkesby. The Loonie has been more volatile after a strong start to the week on starkly contrasting upbeat Canadian vs bleak US jobs data last week. Indeed, Usd/Cad kicked off around 1.3245 and extended losses to 1.3225 at one stage with some interim pressure from the spike in after the Gulf of Oman vessels were targeted. However, the pair is now at new highs circa 1.3385 and eyeing 1.3400 ahead of June 6’s pinnacle at 1.3431.

GBP/EUR/CHF 

All on the receiving end of the firm Buck revival as Cable retreats further from 1.2700+ peaks and the single currency from 1.1300+ at best, with additional negative impulses via dire UK GDP and production, political uncertainty as the Tory leadership race kicked off and no deal Brexit jitters after staunch leaver Boris Johnson romped to victory in the first elimination vote. Note, the Pound did derive some traction from above consensus average earnings, but is now only just keeping its head above 1.2600, though Eur/Gbp is pivoting 0.8900 and close to where the cross started the week as Eur/Usd drifts down towards support ahead of 1.1200 in the form of the 30 DMA (1.1214). Elsewhere, the Franc has lagged fellow safe-havens for the most part, albeit displaying more of that allure against the Euro that had downbeat Eurozone macro news and ongoing Italy-EU budget wrangling to contend with. Usd/Chf is 100+ pips off the lows and back near parity with the SNB reinforcing dovish policy, intervention and stressing that there is more in the monetary policy locker to combat excessive Franc strength given heightened prospects of increased demand and more pronounced downside risks to the economy.

NOK/SEK

The Scandi Crowns are both heading for decent gains on a mixture of bullish technical factors and Norges Bank/Riksbank divergence vs the ECB and other Central Banks as Eur/Nok nestles near the base of 9.8300-7525 parameters and Eur/Sek sits closer to the bottom of a 10.7175-6260 band. Firmer than expected Swedish inflation data has also underpinned the Swedish Krona, while its Norwegian peer was only briefly knocked by a weaker than forecast CPI report as the latest Norges Bank regional survey was upbeat.

EM

Not many regional currencies escaped the overall downturn in risk sentiment, but the Rand was also rocked by a fraud probe against SA Presdident Ramaphosa, the Indian Rupiah had to digest an RBI rate cut and shift to accommodation from neutral, while the Lira was undermined by a ratchet up in Turkish-US angst and decline in reserves after fleeting support from the CBRT that maintained a tightening bias. Conversely, the Real was shielded to an extent by positive news and views on the Brazilian Pension Reform bill front.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 14th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

More than 600 companies and industry trade associations, including Walmart (WMT), Costco (COST) and Target (TGT), have written to the White House urging US President Trump to find a resolution with China to end the ongoing trade war, warning that tariffs on Chinese imports will damage the US economy, job market and be harmful to consumers.

Broadcom (AVGO) shares sunk after market on Thursday, after the Co. cut it FY19 revenue view and warned “we see a broad-based slowdown in the demand environment”. These comments dragged the broader semiconductor sector, including heavyweights Intel (INTC), Nvidia (NVDA) and Qualcomm (QCOM), lower.

DOW

  • 3M (MMM) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) has settled a patent infringement action with South Korea based Tovis and Scientific Games Corp (SGMS), although terms of the settlement were not disclosed.
  • Johnson & Johnson’s (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Janssen unit reports top-line phase 3 results for TREMFYA (Guselkumab) in adults with active psoriatic arthritis.
  • McDonald (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has had its price target raised at Stifel to USD 200 from USD 190, the analyst sees domestic same-restaurant-sales momentum likely continuing in Q2.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) & Twitter (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - The EU has said online platforms must do more to combat online disinformation, including the sharing of data on their efforts, after it uncovered suspected Russian and other attempts to disrupt last month's European Parliament elections.
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is seemingly preparing for a second push into the lending business, the Financial Times reports. The e-commerce giant has placed job ads for a number of positions across Europe, Asia and Seattle.
  • Amgen (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) and Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced that the FDA has approved their KANJINTI drug, which treats certain forms of breast cancer and adenocarcinoma.
  • Broadcom (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) (USD) report Q1 19 adj. EPS 5.21 (exp. 5.18), revenue 5.52bln (exp. 5.69bln), FY19 revenue view cut to 22.5 (exp. 24.41bln), sees a broad base slowdown in the demand environment.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has hired Ed Bowles, who is also Standard Chartered's (SCBFF, STAN LN) European head of corporate and public affairs, as its London-based director of public policy. This comes ahead of plans for the social media platform to release its own cryptocurrency. On which note, over a dozen companies, which include Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), PayPal (PYPL) and Uber (UBER) have signed up to back the new Facebook cryptocurrency, which is to be unveiled next week and launched in 2020, reported the WSJ.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) has had additional requests for tariff exemptions rejected by the US government. Separately, laid off a number of employees in its service team across at several locations across the US, reported Electrek, to which a company spokesperson responded saying the company is “restructuring” some roles in the service department. This comes after recent criticism levied at the electric automaker regarding its customer service.
  • T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services), Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) – A judge has set a pre-trail hearing for next week, as 10 states attempt to block the proposed merger between the two telecoms co.s. These states are claiming that the merger will cost consumers USD 4.5bln per year.

S&P 500

  • CBS Corp’s (CBS) (Communication Services/Media) board, who meet today to discuss the firm’s possible merger with Viacom (VIAB) (Communication Services/Media), are reportedly concerned about taking on Viacom's management team, whilst also paying a premium, given the latter’s history of underperformance, CNBC reports. Reportedly, the controlling shareholder of both CBS and Viacom is favouring Viacom CEO Bakish to become the CEO of the merged company.
  • Expedia (EXPE) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has agreed to settle allegations that it violated U.S. sanctions on Cuba, said the Treasury Department.
  • FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) has been sent an official enquiry by China over parcels that were delivered incorrectly, Chinese outlet Xinhua reported.

OTHER

  • Barnes & Noble (BKS) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) – An investor group has said the bookstore’s recently agreed deal to sell itself to Elliot Management undervalues the company, and is urging the firm to seek more offers. Note: Elliot Management offered USD 6.50 per share, a total of USD 475mln in cash.
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU, FCA IM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) has signed an agreement with European utilities co.s Enel and Engie as it looks to offer its customers charging points for the electric automobiles it plans to roll out soon.
  • Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co’s (GT) (Consumer Discretionary/Auto Components) European competitor, Nokian Tyres (NRE1V FH), has cut its 2019 sales and operating profit guidance, citing softer car demand and ongoing softness in car tyre market.
  • Sony (SNE) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Durables) has received a USD 1.5bln investment from hedge fund Third Point, who have called on the company to spin off its image sensor arm, which it believes will unlock the company's true worth as a worldwide entertainment leader.
  • Uber’s (UBER) (Industrials/Rail & Road) CEO of its self-driving arm has said that the company needs robo-taxis as it is unable to increase the size of its “human driver” fleet fast enough to meet demand.

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • BROADCOM (AVGO) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SUMMIT INSIGHTS
  • LOUISIANA-PACIFIC (LPX) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM MARKET PERFORM AT BMO CAPITAL

subject: US President Trump says Fed Chair Powell is my pick and "I disagree with him entirely" in ABC interview
content:
Via ABC

  • Trump said that the market would be stronger "if we had a different person in the Federal Reserve who wouldn’t have raised interest rates so much”
  • when asked whether he has concerns that his repeated criticism of Fed puts Powell "in a box" he said “Yes, I do, but I’m gonna do it anyway because I’ve waited long enough.”
  • Trump repeated he thinks the market could be 10,000 points higher if the Federal Reserve hadn’t hiked rates last year.
  • Trump repeated that there's no inflation in the US

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are predominantly lower [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.4%] as the risk-off theme prevails
  • The US have reportedly asked the WTO to pause the investigation into China IP until December, and India are reportedly preparing higher tariffs on 20 US goods
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Business Inventories, University of Michigan Sentiment, BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets traded mixed as they awaited Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data, where retails sales beat on expectations, nevertheless Asia-Pac indices remained mixed as risk-off sentiment prevailed. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was lifted by strength in commodity-related stocks but with gains capped due to weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid anticipation of a lower rate environment and with AMP shares heavily pressured after it received compliance orders from the financial regulator APRA. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was also underpinned by the mining sectors which saw Chiyoda as the biggest gainer, while Sony shares were also bolstered after activist investor Loeb called on the Co. to spin off its semiconductor business. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.7%) was subdued and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) was indecisive amid trade uncertainty and after the PBoC’s efforts resulted to a net weekly injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the recent upside in T-notes, while the BoJ was also present in the market with today’s Rinban operation heavily concentrated in the belly of the curve.

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8937 (Prev. 6.8934)

Chinese Retail Sales YY (May) 8.6% vs. Exp. 8.1% (Prev. 7.2%)

- Chinese Industrial Output YY (May) 5.0% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.4%)

- Chinese Urban Investment (YTD)YY (May) 5.6% vs. Exp. 6.1% (Prev. 6.1%)

Chinese President Xi say China will promote steady developments of ties with Iran, no matter how situation changes. (Newswires)

PBoC are to increase re-discount quota by CNY 200bln and increase SLF quota by CNY 100bln on June 14th to maintain ample liquidity for small and medium banks. (Newswires)

US

Over 600 US companies urged US President Trump to resolve the China trade dispute, with Walmart and Target among the signatories in the letter to the White House. (Nikkei)

US have asked the WTO to pause the investigation into China IP until December., according to sources (Newswires)

India are reportedly preparing to impose higher tariffs on over 20 US good next week, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Tory leadership rivals are said to be mulling an alliance to block Boris Johnson from becoming PM. However, Johnson’s supporters have called on 'vanity candidates' to drop out of the Conservative leadership race in order to speed up the process of appointing a new PM. (The Guardian/Telegraph) For reference, Health Secretary Hancock has pulled out of the Tory leadership race. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire said EU ministers reached an agreement on Eurozone budget, while reports later stated that Le Maire commented that progress has been made but Eurozone budget deal still has a long way to go. (AFP/Newswires))

Eurozone Minister have failed to reach an agreement on the EZ budget, budget size was not discussed, talks are to continue in the coming months, according to an official. Subsequently EU’s Moscovici says the European Commission will continue with preparations for disciplinary steps against Italy. (Newswires)

ECB’s Draghi states that the overall effect of ECB monetary policy on bank profitability has been broadly neutral so far. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Military said Navy Destroyer USS Mason is en route to the area where the 2 oil tankers were attacked, while it added it has no interest in engaging in new conflict in the Middle East and that it is ready to defend US interests as well as freedom of navigation. Furthermore, the US released video footage of Iranian military removing an unexploded mine from the Japanese tanker that was attacked in the Gulf of Oman. (Newswires)

Iran categorically rejected the US unfounded claim regarding tanker attacks according to Iranian mission to the UN, while there were also comments from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif that US allegations against Iran without evidence shows the B team is moving to Plan B of sabotaging diplomacy. (Newswires/Twitter)

Turkey’s Foreign Minister states that they will retaliate in the event the US imposes sanctions due to the S-400 missile system. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mostly lower [Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%], with the exception of the SMI (+0.2%), as the region temporarily side-lines the prospect of Fed rate cuts and succumb to the risk-off sentiment as a result of rising US tensions with China, Russia, Germany, Iran, Turkey and India. Sectors are largely in the red with defensive stocks faring better, gains in the healthcare sector are keeping the SMI afloat. Meanwhile, IT names plumbed the depths with the sector heavily underperforming after a warning from Broadcom regarding a slowdown in global chip demand. As such, Infineon (-5.1%), STMicroelectronics (-4.0%), Dialog Semiconductor (-3.1%), ASML (-3.0%) and ASM (-2.7%) are all near the foot of the Stoxx 600. On the flipside, Scor (+2.6%) and Royal Mail (+2.0%) are in positive territory amid positive broker moves.

FX

DXY - The index continues respect resistance above the psychological 97.000 level (on a closing basis) and ahead of the recent range top at 97.370, as safer currency havens outperform amidst heightened geopolitical and global trade tensions. Moreover, the Dollar remains capped by growing expectations that the Fed will flag a rate cut next week following a run of macro data pointing to a more pronounced slowdown in the economy and benign inflation that that challenges the transitory theory put forward by Powell and other at the last FOMC gathering. On that note, impending retail sales and ip reports could cement an ease in July if not this month. DXY currently relatively contained within a 97.154-96.942 range.

JPY/SEK - The Yen has nudged back up towards 108.00 vs the Buck, and is only really lagging behind Gold in the aforementioned risk-off climate plus the Swedish Krona in the G10 stakes due to firmer than forecast CPI and CPIF metrics that keeps the Riksbank on track to raise the repo. However, Usd/Jpy is still encountering underlying bids ahead of the big figure and may also be propped by decent option expiry interest between 108.00 and 108.15 (1 bn). Back to Scandinavia, Eur/Sek has extended post-inflation data declines through technical support at 10.6500 (10 DMA) and briefly below 10.6400 vs 10.7100+ at one stage.

NZD/AUD - The major losers yet again, and with the Kiwi now underperforming after NZ manufacturing PMI only just held above the 50.0 threshold. Nzd/Usd has slipped under 0.6550 towards 0.6525 and Aud/Nzd is pivoting 1.0550 even though the Aussie has relinquished the 0.6900 handle and chart support a pip below amidst another round of more aggressive RBA policy easing calls (NAB now predicting 3 cuts in 2019 from 2 previously and RBC reckons the OCR will be lowered to 0.5% by May next year).

EUR/CAD/CHF/GBP - All lower against the Greenback as well, albeit to a lesser extent compared to the Antipodean Dollars and to varying degrees. The single currency is retreating further from 1.1300 where massive expiries run off (4.4 bn) and the Loonie has reversed to test support ahead of 1.3350 having lost some of Thursday’s oil-powered momentum as crude prices simmer down after the post-tanker attack spike. Meanwhile, the Franc has pared gains across the board with Usd/Chf at the upper end of a 0.9966-26 band and Eur/Chf back above 1.1200 on SNB reflection (renewed and reemphasised convictions to keep NIRP or even cut deeper and continue intervention). Elsewhere, Cable has is now pivoting 1.2650 with independent bearish impulses from the ongoing UK political hiatus and resultant suspension of any real Brexit developments, but BoE Governor Carney may provide some additional impetus later.

EM - No respite for the Lira it seems as Usd/Try rallies through 5.9000 to 5.9300+ and not far from chart resistance around 5.9500, including a 50% Fib of the retracement from last month’s highs to earlier June lows. The latest catalyst, warnings from Turkey’s Foreign Ministry that any US sanctions will be reciprocated.

New Zealand Manufacturing PMI (May) 50.2 (Prev. 53.0, Rev. 52.7). (Newswires)

Swedish CPI YY (May) 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%)

- Swedish CPI MM (May) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.7%)

FIXED INCOME

As another Tory leadership candidate raises the white flag and by default if not design boosts BoJo’s prospects, UK debt has recoiled from marginal new record highs at 130.68 and is struggling to pick up the baton again from a fresh 130.37 Liffe base. However, Bunds continue to climb after fewer, more fleeting and shallower pull-backs, with the 10 year Eurozone benchmark now poised to surpass 172.00 having eclipsed chart ‘resistance’ at 171.97. Similarly, US Treasuries are eyeing upside technical levels, like 127-23 in the 10 year note and in the current safe-haven vs risk-off environment it is conceivable that the symbolical 2% cash yield could be tested, especially with this week’s supply out of the way and if looming data adds more fuel the Fed rate cut fire. Back to Eurex, 172.09 has been flagged on some charts as a level, but again resistance appears futile in the current clime.

COMMODITIES

The energy complex is poised for a weekly loss as the two tanker attacks off the coast of Oman only provided brief reprieve for the declining prices, with trade woes and rising US supply outweighing concerns in the Middle East. This morning also saw the release of the IEA monthly report in which the agency cut their outlook on oil demand growth by 100k BPD, which is in-fitting with the OPEC (70k BPD) and EIA (160k BPD) downgrades to oil demand growth for 2019 released earlier in the week. The report also noted that OPEC supply in May fell to the lowest since 2014 due to Iranian sanctions, in which Iranian oil production fell to the lowest since the 1980s. WTI and Brent are lower on the day and currently pressured by the continuation of the risk aversion. Elsewhere, gold has continued to advance as the yellow metal benefits from the risk-off sentiment, with prices now above the key USD 1350/oz ahead of strong trend-line resistance at USD 1358.50/oz. The rally in gold has spilled into other precious metals with silver hitting one-week highs and platinum gaining almost 1%. In terms of base metals, copper remains subdued amid the broad risk tone whilst Dalian iron ore touched new record highs as Chinese steel mills kept demand steady for the metal.

IEA Monthly Report: cuts 2019 oil demand growth forecast by 100k bpd to 1.2mln bpd

- Sees oil demand growth picking up in H2 2019 to 1.6mln bpd and looks for 1.4mln bpd in 2020, demand for OPEC crude slipping to 29.3mln bpd in 2020.

- OPEC supply in May fell to its lowest level since 2014 amid Iranian sanctions, and declines in Saudi and Nigerian output

- State that Iran production fell 210k BPD in May to 2.4mln, lowest level since late 1980's

- Iran oil exports dropped 480k BPD in May to 810k BPD

Libyan oil production is around 1.25mln BPD according to the Libyan Economy Minister. (Newswires)

In terms of base metals, copper remains subdued amid the broad risk tone whilst Dalian iron ore touched new record highs as Chinese steel mills kept demand steady for the metal.

subject: Fixed Income: Gilts fall behind in the global bond bull run
content: As another Tory leadership candidate raises the white flag and by default if not design boosts BoJo’s prospects, UK debt has recoiled from marginal new record highs at 130.68 and is struggling to pick up the baton again from a fresh 130.37 Liffe base. However, Bunds continue to climb after fewer, more fleeting and shallower pull-backs, with the 10 year Eurozone benchmark now poised to surpass 172.00 having eclipsed chart ‘resistance’ at 171.97. Similarly, US Treasuries are eyeing upside technical levels, like 127-23 in the 10 year note and in the current safe-haven vs risk-off environment it is conceivable that the symbolical 2% cash yield could be tested, especially with this week’s supply out of the way and if looming data adds more fuel the Fed rate cut fire. Back to Eurex, 172.09 has been flagged on some charts as a level, but again resistance appears futile in the current clime.

subject: FX Morning Colour: risk averse regime rumbles into US retail sales
content:
DXY

The index continues respect resistance above the psychological 97.000 level (on a closing basis) and ahead of the recent range top at 97.370, as safer currency havens outperform amidst heightened geopolitical and global trade tensions. Moreover, the Dollar remains capped by growing expectations that the Fed will flag a rate cut next week following a run of macro data pointing to a more pronounced slowdown in the economy and benign inflation that that challenges the transitory theory put forward by Powell and other at the last FOMC gathering. On that note, impending retail sales and ip reports could cement an ease in July if not this month. DXY currently relatively contained within a 97.154-96.942 range.

JPY/SEK

The Yen has nudged back up towards 108.00 vs the Buck, and is only really lagging behind Gold in the aforementioned risk-off climate plus the Swedish Krona in the G10 stakes due to firmer than forecast CPI and CPIF metrics that keeps the Riksbank on track to raise the repo. However, Usd/Jpy is still encountering underlying bids ahead of the big figure and may also be propped by decent option expiry interest between 108.00 and 108.15 (1 bn). Back to Scandinavia, Eur/Sek has extended post-inflation data declines through technical support at 10.6500 (10 DMA) and briefly below 10.6400 vs 10.7100+ at one stage.

NZD/AUD 

The major losers yet again, and with the Kiwi now underperforming after NZ manufacturing PMI only just held above the 50.0 threshold. Nzd/Usd has slipped under 0.6550 towards 0.6525 and Aud/Nzd is pivoting 1.0550 even though the Aussie has relinquished the 0.6900 handle and chart support a pip below amidst another round of more aggressive RBA policy easing calls (NAB now predicting 3 cuts in 2019 from 2 previously and RBC reckons the OCR will be lowered to 0.5% by May next year).

EUR/CAD/CHF/GBP

All lower against the Greenback as well, albeit to a lesser extent compared to the Antipodean Dollars and to varying degrees. The single currency is retreating further from 1.1300 where massive expiries run off (4.4 bn) and the Loonie has reversed to test support ahead of 1.3350 having lost some of Thursday’s oil-powered momentum as crude prices simmer down after the post-tanker attack spike. Meanwhile, the Franc has pared gains across the board with Usd/Chf at the upper end of a 0.9966-26 band and Eur/Chf back above 1.1200 on SNB reflection (renewed and reemphasised convictions to keep NIRP or even cut deeper and continue intervention). Elsewhere, Cable has is now pivoting 1.2650 with independent bearish impulses from the ongoing UK political hiatus and resultant suspension of any real Brexit developments, but BoE Governor Carney may provide some additional impetus later.

EM 

No respite for the Lira it seems as Usd/Try rallies through 5.9000 to 5.9300+ and not far from chart resistance around 5.9500, including a 50% Fib of the retracement from last month’s highs to earlier June lows. The latest catalyst, warnings from Turkey’s Foreign Ministry that any US sanctions will be reciprocated.

subject: Libyan oil production is around 1.25mln BPD according to the Libyan Economy Minister
IEA Monthly Report: cuts 2019 oil demand growth forecast by 100k bpd to 1.2mln bpd
content:
• Sees oil demand growth picking up in H2 2019 to 1.6mln bpd and looks for 1.4mln bpd in 2020
  • Sees demand for OPEC crude slipping to 29.3mln bpd in 2020
  • OPEC supply in May fell to its lowest level since 2014 amid Iranian sanctions, and declines in Saudi and Nigerian output
  • Non-OPEC supply growth will accelerate from 1.9mln bpd this year to 2.3mln bpd in 2020
  • OECD oil stocks rose by 15.8mln bbls to 2 883mln bbls, and are slightly above the five-year average
  • Global refinery throughput in May was at its lowest level in two years on maintenance and unplanned outages
  • State that Iran production fell 210k BPD in May to 2.4mln, lowest level since late 1980's
  • Iran oil exports dropped 480k BPD in May to 810k BPD
analysis_details: IEA cut their outlook on oil demand growth by 100k BPD, which is in-line with OPEC (70k BPD) and EIA (160k BPD) downgraded to oil demand growth for 2019 released earlier in the week.

subject: Gilts also approach last Friday’s pinnacle, Short Sterling strip maintains recovery mojo
content: Mixed Chinese data has not derailed the broad bond rally, as Turkey ups the ante on the geopolitical front and US-China/global trade strains show little sign of waning. Indeed, Bunds have now breached their previous contract best, albeit fractionally at 171.89 (so far) and Gilts got to within 3 ticks at 130.64, while the 10 year US Treasury yield is drifting back down towards 2% amidst heightened risk aversion that is now spilling over into equities. Back to Liffe, 3 month contracts are 0.5-3 ticks ahead and clawing back more losses spurred by better than expected UK wage data and hawkish-leaning BoE commentary.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

14th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as looming Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data clouded over the lead from US, where the energy sector outperformed on geopolitical concerns after a suspected Iranian attack on oil vessels in the Gulf of Oman. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was lifted by strength in commodity-related stocks but with gains capped due to weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid anticipation of a lower rate environment and with AMP shares heavily pressured after it received compliance orders from the financial regulator APRA. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was also underpinned by the mining sectors which saw Chiyoda as the biggest gainer, while Sony shares were also bolstered after activist investor Loeb called on the Co. to spin off its semiconductor business. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) was subdued and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) was indecisive amid trade uncertainty, cautiousness heading into the key Chinese data and after the PBoC’s efforts resulted to a net weekly injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain.

subject: Chinese President Xi say China will promote steady developments of ties with Iran, no matter how situation changes
Mega 1.1300 Eur/Usd expiry among today's options
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 14th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are mixed, pulled between the positive Wall St. lead and impending Chinese data at 08:00BST
  • US Secretary of State Pompeo formally blamed Iran for the Oman tanker attacks
  • NEC Director Kudlow states that China has broken WTO terms on trade, as such US President Trump is taking action
  • Looking ahead highlights include, Chinese Industrial Output & Retail Sales, EZ CPI (Final), US Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Business Inventories, University of Michigan Sentiment, IEA Monthly Report, ECB’s Lautenschlager & BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets traded mixed as looming Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data clouded over the lead from US, where the energy sector outperformed on geopolitical concerns after a suspected Iranian attack on oil vessels in the Gulf of Oman. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was lifted by strength in commodity-related stocks but with gains capped due to weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid anticipation of a lower rate environment and with AMP shares heavily pressured after it received compliance orders from the financial regulator APRA. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was also underpinned by the mining sectors which saw Chiyoda as the biggest gainer, while Sony shares were also bolstered after activist investor Loeb called on the Co. to spin off its semiconductor business. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) was subdued and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) was indecisive amid trade uncertainty, cautiousness heading into the key Chinese data and after the PBoC’s efforts resulted to a net weekly injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the recent upside in T-notes, while the BoJ was also present in the market with today’s Rinban operation heavily concentrated in the belly of the curve.

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8937 (Prev. 6.8934)

US NEC Director Kudlow said China has broken WTO terms on trade and that President Trump is taking action, while he also commented that the White House intends for Trump to meet Xi at the G20 although it is not yet formalised. In related news, an administration spokesman also suggested "it looks like we're moving that way" regarding a Trump-Xi meeting at the G20. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond said more money will be available for the future PM to spend in a smooth and orderly Brexit. (Newswires)

DUP’s Donaldson said Dublin is driving the UK towards a no deal Brexit and is using the border as a bargaining chip. (Newswires)

UK Tory leadership rivals are said to be mulling an alliance to block Boris Johnson from becoming PM. However, Johnson’s supporters have called on 'vanity candidates' to drop out of the Conservative leadership race in order to speed up the process of appointing a new PM. (The Guardian/Telegraph)

Former UK Leader of the House Leadsom could support Sajid Javid in the leadership race. Separately, Health Secretary Hancock is reportedly considering pulling out of the Tory leadership race, after receiving 20 votes in round one; having discussed a potential alliance with Michael Gove and Sajid Javid’s teams, with a decision expected shorty. For reference, candidates who wish to drop out of the leadership contest have been asked by the 1922 Committee to do so by Friday lunchtime. (Times/BBC/Guardian)

French Finance Minister Le Maire said EU ministers reached an agreement on Eurozone budget, while reports later stated that Le Maire commented that progress has been made but Eurozone budget deal still has a long way to go. (AFP/Newswires))

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was steady and held above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s safe-haven support and as its transatlantic counterparts languished after EUR/USD recently failed to reclaim the 1.1300 handle and with GBP/USD at a sub-1.2700 level following the First Ballot of the Tory leadership race. Elsewhere, JPY remained bolstered by recent geopolitical concerns and antipodeans were softer ahead of the key China data, with AUD/USD also subdued by further dovish RBA calls in which NAB now forecast a total of 3 cuts this year vs. Prev. 2 and with RBC expecting the Cash Rate to be lowered to as low as 0.50% by May next year, while NZD/USD underperformed following soft New Zealand Business PMI data.

New Zealand Manufacturing PMI (May) 50.2 (Prev. 53.0, Rev. 52.7). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures marginally higher as it resumed its geopolitical-fuelled advances following the oil tanker attack which the US have blamed on Iran, while the US have also deployed a US Navy Destroyer to the region in what is viewed as a deterrence to further attacks. Elsewhere, gold prices edged mild gains amid safe-haven demand but with gains capped by a sturdy greenback, while copper was lacklustre amid the indecisive tone in the region which was at a contrast to the early surges in Chinese benchmark iron ore, which rose to fresh record highs once again.

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih said Saudi will take all measures to protect itself and is committed to providing guaranteed oil supplies to international markets, while he added that Aramco has increased readiness to deal with attacks. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Iran is not ready to make a deal with the US and Secretary of State Pompeo stated that Iran is responsible for today's tanker attacks, while Pompeo added that Iran continues to actively work to interrupt flows of oil and have rejected Japan PM Abe's outreach for diplomacy. (Newswires)

US Military said Navy Destroyer USS Mason is en route to the area where the 2 oil tankers were attacked, while it added it has no interest in engaging in new conflict in the Middle East and that it is ready to defend US interests as well as freedom of navigation. Furthermore, the US released video footage of Iranian military removing an unexploded mine from the Japanese tanker that was attacked in the Gulf of Oman. (Newswires)

White House official said the US is discussing options with allies on the protection of international shipping to the Gulf and want to ensure freedom of navigation, while an official also suggested that more tanker attacks could ensue and does not think it is over. (Newswires)

US Senator Rubio said the attacks in the Gulf of Oman today by Quds Force of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard has created a very dangerous situation in the region. (Newswires)

Iran categorically rejected the US unfounded claim regarding tanker attacks according to Iranian mission to the UN, while there were also comments from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif that US allegations against Iran without evidence shows the B team is moving to Plan B of sabotaging diplomacy. (Newswires/Twitter)

US

The Treasury curve bull-steepened after geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, while traders also cited increasing expectations of Fed rate cuts pushing shorter-dated yields lower. 2-year yields came in by over 6bps, while longer-dated yields were around 2.5bps lower. The US Treasury auctioned 30-year debt, stopping through the screens by 0.4bps, while cover rose vs recent averages and the prior auction; the foreign bid remained (as was seen in all auctions this week), with indirect participation remaining above the previous auction as well as recent averages. Friday’s retail sales data is the final piece of the data puzzle ahead of next week’s FOMC meeting; markets are pricing a 28% chance of a rate cut at the June meeting (which comes ahead of the G20 on 28-29th June, which will set the tone for trade wars, and global growth expectations); accordingly there is more aggressive pricing for a July rate cut, which is now over 100% implied, according to money markets, suggesting that the market is increasingly pricing in the possibility of a 50bps rate cut, instead of the ‘usual’ 25bps. At settlement, major curve spreads were wider, with 2s30s steepening by 3.5bps. US T-note futures (M9) 11+ ticks higher at 127-00.

Over 600 US companies urged US President Trump to resolve the China trade dispute, with Walmart and Target among the signatories in the letter to the White House. (Nikkei)

White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders is to leave her position at the end of the month. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (+0.1%) is kept afloat as strength in commodity-related stocks is counterbalanced by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid anticipation of a lower interest rate environment and with AMP shares heavily pressured after it received compliance orders from the financial regulator APRA. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) is also underpinned by the mining sectors which has seen Chiyoda as the biggest gainer, while Sony shares also outperform after activist investor Loeb called on the Co. to spin off its semiconductor business. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) is subdued and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) trades indecisive amid trade uncertainty, cautiousness heading into the key Chinese data and with the PBoC’s efforts resulting to a net weekly injection of CNY 65bln vs. last week’s CNY 320bln net drain.

In FX markets, the DXY is steady and holds above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s safe-haven support and as its transatlantic counterparts languish after EUR/USD recently failed to reclaim the 1.1300 handle and with GBP/USD at a sub-1.2700 level following the First Ballot of the Tory leadership race in which devout Brexiteer Boris Johnson received the most support with 114 votes vs. nearest trailing candidate Jeremy Hunt at 43 votes. Elsewhere, the JPY remains bolstered by recent geopolitical concerns and antipodeans are softer ahead of the key China data, with AUD/USD subdued by further dovish RBA calls in which NAB now forecast a total of 3 cuts this year vs. Prev. 2 and with RBC expecting the Cash Rate to be lowered to as low as 0.50% by May next year, while NZD/USD underperforms following softer New Zealand Business PMI data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they track recent upside in T-notes, while the BoJ are also present in the market with today’s Rinban operation heavily concentrated in the belly of the curve.

Air China (753 HK) - Co. passenger traffic rose 8.3% in May. (Newswires)

China Vanke (2202 HK) - Co. shareholder Jusgenghua pledged around 41.7mln shares in the Co. as collateral. (Newswires)

Huawei - Co. executive said the tech firm is in the process of potentially launching replacement software for Google's (GOOG) Android. (Newswires)

Financials - HSBC (5 HK) and Bank of China HK (2388 HK) are to increase mortgage rates for some loans. (Newswires)

Protests - Various banks in Hong Kong states that they will reopen certain branches which were shut due to protests. (Newswires)

SOEs - China is said to target profit growth of 9% for state-owned enterprises for 2019. (Newswires)

Steel - China imposes anti-dumping duties on certain alloy steel seamless tubes and pipes imported from US and EU. (Newswires)

Trade

US NEC Director Kudlow said China has broken WTO terms on trade and that President Trump is taking action, while he also commented that the White House intends for Trump to meet Xi at the G20 although it is not yet formalised. In related news, an administration spokesman also suggested "it looks like we're moving that way" regarding a Trump-Xi meeting at the G20. (Newswires)

Mofcom spokesman Gao Fang said China will fight to the end if the US insists on escalating and that China will not back down regarding principle issues in trade talks. (Newswires)

China said Canada are entirely to blame for the recent diplomatic spat and have called for the immediate release of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou. (CBC News)
